questions.text: A 4-year-old boy is brought to the physician because of a generalized rash for 3 days. During this period, he has had severe itching and was not able to sleep well. He has also had fever, headache, and some muscle pain. Five days ago, he had a runny nose which subsided with over-the-counter medications. He returned from a camping trip 1 week ago. He attends a daycare center. The patient is at the 55th percentile for height and at the 50th percentile for weight. His temperature is 38.2°C (100.7°F), pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows several macules, papules, and crusted lesions over his face, trunk, and extremities. There are a few fluid-filled vesicles over his abdomen and back. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

This patient had coryza and fever, both of which are often seen in patients with measles. However, measles typically manifests with a nonpruritic, erythematous, maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem, which is markedly different from this patient's lesions (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions). Also, this boy does not have any of the symptoms that are typically concomitantly present in measles, such as cough, conjunctivitis, or generalized lymphadenopathy.

B) INCORRECT:

This patient was on a recent hiking trip, putting him at risk for skin exposure to urushiol-containing plants, which can result in urushiol-induced contact dermatitis. Similar to this boy's skin findings, the rash seen in urushiol-induced dermatitis is also highly pruritic and vesicular. However, it is usually localized to where the plant came into contact with the skin (e.g., the legs, arms, hands). Also, a contact dermatitis rash develops 12–48 hours after antigen exposure; this patient returned from his camping trip 4 days before the onset of his symptoms.
Image Description:

An erythematous rash with numerous small vesicles in a linear pattern can be seen on the left forearm.

This rash is typical of mild allergic contact dermatitis caused by urushiol-containing plants (e.g., poison oak). In more severe cases, bullae and pronounced edema may be present.

C) INCORRECT:

The rash seen in scarlet fever is typically fine, erythematous, and maculopapular (often described as sandpaper-like), unlike in this patient who presents with macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions. Also, apart from fever, he does not have any symptoms that are characteristically seen in scarlet fever (e.g., throat pain, cervical lymphadenopathy).

D) INCORRECT:

Roseola infantum primarily affects children between 2 months and 2 years of age and typically manifests with a very high fever that ends abruptly before the sudden appearance of a rash. In contrast, this patient's fever and exanthema are present at the same time. Also, his rash is both maculopapular and papulovesicular, different from the rose-pink maculopapular, patchy, blanching exanthem typically seen in roseola infantum. In addition, roseola infantum almost always presents with cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy.

E) CORRECT:

This patient's constitutional symptoms (fever, headache, and myalgia) along with a highly pruritic, generalized rash with multiple lesions in different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) are characteristic of chickenpox. Chickenpox is usually a clinical diagnosis made on the basis of the characteristic rash, although further tests may be necessary in atypical or complicated cases (e.g., older or immunosuppressed patients, pregnant women). A PCR from skin lesions to evaluate for VZV DNA is the preferred test for confirmation.

F) INCORRECT:

Patients with erythema infectiosum also present with fever and a pruritic rash. However, erythema infectiosum rash is usually only mildly pruritic and initially pronounced on the cheeks (i.e., slapped‑cheek rash) before spreading to the extremities and trunk where it adopts a lace-like and reticular appearance. This patient's highly pruritic rash with fluid-filled vesicles and crusted lesions is inconsistent with erythema infectiosum.

G) INCORRECT:

The patient was on a hiking trip which puts him at risk for tick bites and contracting tick-borne diseases such as Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF). Although fever, headache, and myalgia are commonly seen in patients with RMSF, these symptoms usually occur several days prior to the onset of a rash. Also, the rash seen in RMSF is not associated with crusts and vesicles and typically follows a particular pattern that begins on the wrists and ankles, then spreads to the trunk, palms, and soles.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent, macules are visible on this patient's forearm.

This rash is suggestive of Rocky Mountain spotted fever (RMSF), a tick-borne disease caused by Rickettsia rickettsii bacteria. The distal extremities are usually affected first; the rash then spreads toward the proximal extremities and the trunk (the face, however, is usually spared).

H) INCORRECT:

While this patient's fever, headache, myalgia, coryza, and development of a rash could be signs of rubella, the rash seen in rubella is usually only mildly pruritic, maculopapular, and not associated with any vesicles or crusted lesions. Also, affected children commonly have concomitant postauricular and/or suboccipital lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: The causative pathogen in this patient's case can remain dormant in dorsal root ganglia and get reactivated after several years, leading to a dermatomal rash with painful blistering.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy is brought to the emergency department because of a generalized pruritic rash for 14 hours. Five days ago, he had pink eyes that resolved spontaneously. He has acute lymphoblastic leukemia. He has received 3 cycles of chemotherapy with vincristine, asparaginase, dexamethasone, and doxorubicin. His last treatment cycle was 2 weeks ago. The patient's other medications include multivitamin supplements. His temperature is 38°C (100.4°F), pulse 90/min, and blood pressure is 105/65 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows multiple crops of macules and papules over the face, trunk, and extremities. There are also excoriation marks and crusted lesions. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Administration of vitamin A can reduce mortality in patients with measles. Measles commonly manifests with a prodromal stage of coryza, cough, and conjunctivitis and during the exanthem stage, high fever is present. The measles rash appears as an erythematous maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem. Although this boy had conjunctivitis, he only has a mild fever. Also, he did not have any other prodrome and his skin findings are more consistent with chickenpox. Vitamin A administration has not been proven to be beneficial in patients with chickenpox.

B) INCORRECT:

Varicella-zoster (VZV) immunoglobulin should be administered in immunosuppressed individuals with no evidence of immunity as postexposure prophylaxis (passive immunization) to chickenpox, to prevent disease onset or mitigate the disease course. Although VZV immunoglobulin may be given as late as 10 days following exposure, maximum benefit is conferred when given as soon as possible. However, there is no evidence that postexposure prophylaxis administration is helpful in treating already established infections with VZV, such as chickenpox or shingles; therefore, it is not recommended.

C) INCORRECT:

In healthy children, chickenpox generally has a benign course and heals without any consequences. Symptomatic treatment with topical applications (e.g., calamine lotion) or oral H1-antihistamines for pruritus is generally adequate. Because this child has a history of acute leukemia and a recent course of chemotherapy, he is immunocompromised and at greater risk of the disease taking a generalized or even fatal course. Therefore, symptomatic therapy alone is not sufficient; specific treatment should be initiated.

D) CORRECT:

Acyclovir is the antiviral drug of choice used to treat chickenpox in immunocompromised patients. These individuals are at risk of the disease taking a generalized or even fatal course. This patient should receive antiviral treatment within 24 hours of onset of the varicella rash to reduce the duration and the severity of the disease, as well as the risk of complications.

Chickenpox should also be treated in adults, unvaccinated adolescents, individuals on long-term salicylate therapy (due to an increased risk of Reye syndrome), children taking corticosteroids, and in patients with a history of chronic skin or lung disease. Possible serious complications that may result from chickenpox, particularly in immunocompromised individuals, include pneumonia, sepsis, encephalitis, acute cerebellitis, or bleeding disorders.

E) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin V may be used to treat bacterial infections such as scarlet fever, which is a common cause of childhood rashes. This patient does not display the typical findings of scarlet fever (e.g., tonsillopharyngitis, flush cheeks, perioral pallor) and his rash with crusted lesions looks different from the sandpaper-like rash normally associated with scarlet fever. Because his findings suggest chickenpox (caused by a viral infection), antibiotics are of no use.
questions.hint: This child has a widespread, severely pruritic rash that presents with lesions at various stages (macules, papules, and crusted lesions), which is indicative of chickenpox. He recently finished a cycle of chemotherapy and he has acute leukemia, both of which make him more susceptible to infection.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is brought to the physician because of a generalized pruritic rash for 3 days. Her mother has noticed fluid oozing from some of the lesions. She was born at term and has been healthy except for an episode of bronchitis 4 months ago that was treated with azithromycin. There is no family history of serious illness. Her immunization records are unavailable. She attends elementary school but has missed the last 5 days. She appears healthy. Her temperature is 38°C (100.4°F). Examination shows a maculopapular rash with crusted lesions and vesicles over the entire body, including the scalp.  Her hemoglobin concentration is 13.1 g/dL, leukocyte count is 9800/mm3, and platelet count is 319,000/mm3. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy with acyclovir for chickenpox in children ≤ 12 years of age is only indicated if the child is at a high risk of developing complications; for example, those taking intermittent/chronic glucocorticoids (risk of disseminated varicella infection and complications like pneumonia), those taking long-term salicylates (risk of Reye syndrome), and in those who have a pre-existing skin/pulmonary disease (risk of secondary bacterial infection). Since this child has none of the above-mentioned risk factors, acyclovir therapy is not indicated.

B) INCORRECT:

Vitamin A supplementation is recommended by the WHO for children infected with the measles virus. Vitamin A enhances the barrier function of ocular, respiratory, and gastrointestinal epithelium, and has been proven to decrease the severity of measles infection. Although measles can also present with fever and rash, crusted/vesicular lesions are not seen. Children with measles typically feel more ill and have generalized lymphadenopathy.

C) INCORRECT:

A rapid strep test is done via pharyngeal swab in patients with scarlet fever, which also presents with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. Unlike this child's maculopapular and vesicular rash with crusted lesions, the characteristic rash of scarlet fever is fine, erythematous, sandpaper-like, and blanches on pressure. Also, children with scarlet fever usually have odynophagia, inflamed pharyngeal mucosa, and cervical lymphadenopathy, all of which are absent here.

D) INCORRECT:

A Tzanck test is indicated when the clinical diagnosis of a blistering skin disease is unclear (e.g., in atypical or complicated disease). The test can also be considered in children with a diffuse vesicular rash if the clinical diagnosis is in doubt. Since this child has presented with the characteristic presentation of a specific viral exanthem (simultaneous presence of all stages of the rash), a clinical diagnosis is sufficient.

E) INCORRECT:

Although measles presents with fever and rash, the characteristic measles rash is erythematous, maculopapular, and lacks vesicles or crusted lesions. Also, children with measles typically feel very ill and have generalized lymphadenopathy.

F) CORRECT:

Primary varicella infection (chickenpox) in a healthy child ≤ 12 years is usually a mild, self-limiting infection, which is managed with supportive therapy (e.g., acetaminophen for fever and antipruritic agents). Calamine lotion (active ingredient is zinc oxide) is an antipruritic drug that can be used to decrease itching. Antihistamines can also be used to control pruritus. To prevent scratching and secondary bacterial infection of the vesicle, the child's fingernails should be kept short.

G) INCORRECT:

Although rubella presents with fever and a maculopapular rash, children with rubella typically also have postauricular and suboccipital lymphadenopathy and a flu-like prodrome (sore throat, arthralgia). Additionally, vesicles and crusted lesions are not seen in rubella.

H) INCORRECT:

Oral penicillin is the treatment of choice for scarlet fever, which also presents with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. Unlike this child's maculopapular and vesicular rash with crusted lesions, the characteristic rash of scarlet fever is fine, erythematous, sandpaper-like, and blanches on pressure. Children with scarlet fever usually have odynophagia and cervical lymphadenopathy, which are absent here.
questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash all over the body with macules, papules, crusted and vesicular lesions (simultaneous presence of all stages of the rash) indicates chickenpox.

questions.text: An 18-month-old boy is brought to the physician by his mother because of a 2-day history of fever and a pruritic rash that started on his trunk and then progressed to his face and extremities. He has not received any childhood vaccinations because his parents believe that they are dangerous. His temperature is 38.0°C (100.4°F). A photograph of the rash is shown. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Nonbullous impetigo, which can be caused by Staphylococcus aureus or Streptococcus pyogenes, is the most common skin infection in children. It is characterized by a localized lesion (most commonly on the face and extremities) that begins as an erythematous papule and progresses to a pustule that may rupture and dry (i.e., honey-colored crusts). Regional lymphadenopathy can also be present. This patient's generalized rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) on his trunk, face, and extremities, is not consistent with nonbullous impetigo.
Image Description:

Confluent erosions and honey-colored crusts with an erythematous base are visible on the face, forehead, temporal region, and part of the neck. As in this photo, vesicles may not always be present or noticeable.

B) INCORRECT:

Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum or sixth disease), which is primarily caused by HHV-6 and, less frequently, by HHV-7, can manifest with a generalized rash and fever. However, children typically present with a 3–7 day history of persistent high-grade fever (may present as febrile seizures) that rapidly subsides, followed by the development of a rose-pink, nonpruritic, blanching maculopapular rash that begins on the trunk. In contrast, this patient's fever and rash appeared simultaneously. Additional features of roseola infantum may include conjunctivitis, orbital edema, inflammation of the tympanic membranes, lymphadenopathy, upper respiratory tract symptoms, and Nagayama spots, none of which are seen in this patient.

C) CORRECT:

Varicella (chickenpox) is caused by the varicella-zoster virus (HHV-3) and is characterized by fever and a generalized pruritic rash in various stages of healing that typically begins on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities. Chickenpox is no longer as common in the United States following the introduction of the varicella vaccine in 1995. Children between 12–15 months of age should receive their first dose of the vaccine and a second dose between ages 4–6.

D) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus which remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia. It most commonly occurs in adults over the age of 50 years and classically presents as a painful vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. Fever, headaches, and paresthesias may also occur. This patient's rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) on his trunk, face, and extremities, is not consistent with herpes zoster.
Image Description:

Multiple, partly confluent vesicles with a strict dermatomal distribution are visible.

This appearance is suggestive of shingles.

E) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) should be considered in an unvaccinated child with fever and a generalized rash. However, the measles rash is typically confluent, nonpruritic, and characteristically begins on the face and moves downward, as opposed to this boy's rash. In addition, the rash is usually preceded by a constellation of symptoms including cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and enanthem with Koplik spots, none of which are seen in this patient.

F) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) should be considered in an unvaccinated child with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. However, the rubella rash is typically maculopapular and begins on the face and moves downward (as opposed to this patient's rash) sparing the palms and soles. In addition, rubella is characterized by a prodromal phase in which patients usually present with post-auricular and/or suboccipital lymphadenopathy, neither of which are seen in this child.

G) INCORRECT:

Erythema infectiosum (fifth disease), which is caused by parvovirus B19, can manifest with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. However, the rash is typically only mildly pruritic and initially appears on the cheeks (“slapped-cheek” rash) before spreading to the trunk and extremities, where it has a lace-like, reticular appearance as it clears. This patient's rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions), is not consistent with erythema infectiosum.
questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash with simultaneous occurrence of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions indicates infection with human herpesvirus 3.

questions.text: A 7-year-old girl is brought to the physician by her father because of a 2-day history of fever and malaise. Yesterday, she developed a rash on her chest that has since spread to her shoulders, arms, neck, face, and stomach area. She tries her best not to scratch her body but describes the rash as “very itchy.” She has not had nausea, vomiting, or diarrhea. Her mother had measles during childhood but no other rashes. She has only received immunization for hepatitis B because her mother, who has never been vaccinated, is skeptical about “the whole vaccination thing.” The girl appears lethargic. Her temperature is 38.3°C (100.9°F), pulse is 90/min, respirations are 17/min, and blood pressure is 126/84 mm Hg. Examination of the skin shows a papular rash with vesicles and crusted lesions. The remainder of the physical examination shows no abnormalities. Three days ago, the family visited the patient's 10-day-old brother at the neonatal intensive care unit. He was born at 31 weeks' gestation and weighed 1390 g (3 lb 1 oz) at birth. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management for the patient's brother?

choices.text: Observe and reevaluate the next day

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

A watchful waiting approach is indicated in patients who have a low risk of developing complications from chickenpox. Because premature newborns are at increased risk of developing complications from VZV infection, a watchful waiting approach is not appropriate.

B) INCORRECT:

Acyclovir is used to treat chickenpox in individuals who are at high risk of developing complications, such as immunocompromised patients, unvaccinated adolescents ≥ 13 years of age, adults, and individuals on long-term salicylates therapy. This patient's newborn brother does not yet have chickenpox; therefore, treatment with antiviral therapy is not indicated. In this case, the focus must be on disease prevention.

C) INCORRECT:

A live attenuated vaccine is used to actively immunize against varicella. Following varicella exposure, postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) with active immunization is indicated for immunocompetent individuals who are not pregnant and not yet immune against varicella (either as a result of previous VZV infection or completed routine childhood varicella immunization); the varicella vaccine would be used as PEP for this patient's mother. However, because guidelines do not permit the use of the varicella vaccine before the age of 12 months, a different method of PEP is indicated for this patient's brother.

D) CORRECT:

The use of VZV immunoglobulin (passive immunization) as postexposure prophylaxis (PEP) for chickenpox is indicated in premature neonates born after 28 weeks' gestation to mothers with no evidence of immunity to VZV, as seen here (this patient's mother has never had chickenpox). PEP prevents disease onset or mitigates the course of the disease and must be given within 10 days following exposure (ideally within 4 days). Other indications for passive postexposure immunoprophylaxis include newborns born before 28 weeks' gestation regardless of the mother's immunity status, pregnant women or immunosuppressed patients with no evidence of immunity to VZV, and newborns whose mother was infected between 5 days before and up to 2 days after birth.

E) INCORRECT:

Conjugate polysaccharide vaccines include vaccines against Haemophilus influenzae serotype b, Streptococcus pneumoniae, Neisseria meningitidis, and Salmonella typhi. Active immunization against chickenpox is performed with a different type of vaccine. The H. influenzae serotype b (Hib) vaccine and S. pneumoniae conjugate vaccine (PCV15, PCV20) would be administered to the patient's brother as a part of routine immunization but only at 2 months of age. The N. meningitidis conjugate vaccine is only indicated at 11–12 years of age and the S. typhi conjugate vaccine is not a part of the routine immunization schedule.

F) INCORRECT:

Measurement of specific anti-VZV IgG titers is performed as part of antenatal care for pregnant women who have not had chickenpox or not received the varicella vaccine in order to determine immunity against VZV and the need for post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) against varicella. In cases of varicella exposure in preterm neonates born to a mother with no evidence of immunity to VZV, guidelines do not recommend serological testing before administering PEP.
questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash that consists of papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions in conjunction with fever, malaise, and incomplete immunizations strongly suggests chickenpox. Hospitalized premature newborns are at increased risk of complications from varicella-zoster virus (VZV) infection.

questions.text:
An 11-month-old boy presents with a 2-day history of pruritic rash. His mother reports that he has had fever for the past 2 days and that he seems more tired and less hungry than usual. He is up to date on all of his vaccinations. His mother has been administering ibuprofen for symptom control.
His vital signs are significant only for a temperature of 38.4°C. An erythematous rash with overlying vesicles is apparent on his trunk and extremities, with a close-up image of one of the vesicles noted here (figure). There are excoriated, crusted papules on his face. His mother notes that the facial rash started as vesicles similar to those on his trunk and extremities. The rest of the examination is unremarkable.
Which one of the following conditions is the most likely cause of this patient’s presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Molluscum contagiosum, which is caused by a poxvirus, results in a scattered pustular rash, frequently with central umbilication. It is not typically diffusely distributed and is not associated with other systemic symptoms.

B) INCORRECT:

The rash associated with parvovirus infection is often preceded by nonspecific, flulike symptoms, which then give way to a characteristic erythematous malar (“slapped cheek”) rash. This facial rash is often followed by a generalized reticular rash, by which point the patient’s systemic symptoms have usually resolved.

C) INCORRECT:

Variola virus infection (smallpox) is associated with fever and rash, and the vesicular eruption associated with variola may look very similar to that of varicella. However, smallpox was eradicated in 1979 after a successful vaccination program worldwide.

D) CORRECT:

The pruritic rash of varicella, which results from infection with the varicella-zoster virus, is usually preceded by a short prodrome of fever, malaise, and pharyngitis. Lesions start as erythematous macules that progress to the classic “dewdrop on rose petal” vesicles and, later, to pustules or crusted papules. New crops of lesions can appear for 4 days, and the patient will have lesions in all stages of development at the same time.

Universal vaccination has significantly reduced the incidence of varicella in all age groups. The first dose of varicella vaccine should be administered between 12 and 15 months of age, with a second dose given at 4 to 6 years. Vaccinated individuals can still develop clinical chickenpox, but their clinical course is usually significantly milder than that of unvaccinated patients. This patient is too young to have received his first varicella vaccination.

Key learning point: Lesions that progress from erythematous macules to classic vesicles and later to pustules or crusted papules are most consistent with infection from varicella-zoster virus.
Image Description:

Photograph of skin lesions in various stages of evolution

Multiple cutaneous lesions are visible across the skin surface. Early lesions appear as erythematous macules, some of which have progressed to raised papules. Several papules have developed into superficial vesicles filled with clear fluid on an erythematous base. Older lesions show umbilicated pustules and crusting.

This polymorphic eruption is characteristic of varicella.

E) INCORRECT:

Drug eruptions can occur subsequent to the administration of a variety of medications, including antibiotics and ibuprofen. The associated rash typically manifests as a maculopapular skin eruption or sometimes targetoid and can be associated with mucous membrane ulcerations. The rash in this patient is vesicular and less consistent with a drug eruption.

questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash with simultaneous occurrence of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions indicates infection with human herpesvirus 3.

questions.text:
A 6-year-old boy is brought to the clinic by his parents due to stumbling and difficulty standing that began earlier today. His gait is unsteady, and he occasionally sways when sitting. He recovered from chickenpox about two weeks ago. His speech is slightly slurred, but muscle strength is normal. He does not have a headache or neck stiffness. Reflexes are normal.
Which diagnosis best explains this presentation?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Guillain-Barré syndrome is a post-infectious demyelinating condition presenting with progressive, symmetric weakness and reduced or absent reflexes. The patient's intact muscle strength and normal reflexes, along with the absence of an ascending weakness pattern, do not support this diagnosis.

B) INCORRECT:

Meningitis typically presents with neck stiffness, headache, and fever, which are absent here. The patient's symptoms suggest a localized cerebellar syndrome with ataxia and slurred speech, preserved muscle strength, and normal reflexes, rather than a diffuse meningeal process.

C) CORRECT:

Acute cerebellar ataxia is an immune-mediated condition that often occurs in children 1–3 weeks after a varicella infection. It involves an inflammatory response affecting the cerebellum, particularly Purkinje cells, leading to coordination disruption. Clinically, it manifests as sudden-onset gait instability, dysmetria, and dysarthria, while muscle strength and deep tendon reflexes remain normal. The recent varicella infection, without systemic signs like fever or meningeal irritation, supports this diagnosis by localizing the pathology to the cerebellum and excluding other central nervous system processes.

Key learning point: Acute cerebellar ataxia is a common post-infectious complication in children, often following viral infections like chickenpox, characterized by sudden onset of ataxia.

D) INCORRECT:

Brainstem encephalitis typically presents with cranial nerve deficits, altered consciousness, and meningeal irritation signs, such as headache and neck stiffness, which are absent here. The child's symptoms are limited to gait instability and slurred speech, without systemic or multifocal neurological impairments, suggesting a more localized dysfunction.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old man presents with three days of a pruritic rash that began on his upper trunk, accompanied by fever, malaise, and mild shortness of breath. He has a history of heavy smoking. The rash consists of erythematous macules evolving to clear vesicles and has spread to his face, scalp, and arms. Examination reveals multiple lesions in various stages of development. Bilateral crackles are heard at the lung bases (see report).


Respiratory rate
20 breaths/min


Oxygen saturation
92% on room air


Chest radiograph: Diffuse patchy infiltrates
Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Oral acyclovir is used in mild varicella cases due to ease of administration. However, the patient's severe respiratory symptoms, including hypoxemia and bilateral pulmonary infiltrates, require intravenous acyclovir for adequate drug levels. Heavy smoking increases the risk of severe varicella pneumonia, necessitating a more aggressive approach.

B) INCORRECT:

High-dose intravenous corticosteroids are used for severe pulmonary inflammation or immune-mediated lung injury. However, the patient's presentation aligns with varicella pneumonia, a viral infection. Corticosteroids do not inhibit viral replication and may worsen the infection due to their immunosuppressive effects. The primary goal is to target viral replication directly.

C) CORRECT:

The patient's symptoms, including a pruritic rash evolving from macules to vesicles and respiratory distress with diffuse patchy infiltrates on chest radiograph, suggest varicella pneumonia. This condition is a complication of primary varicella infection in adults, especially in heavy smokers. Intravenous acyclovir is indicated due to its ability to achieve high plasma and tissue concentrations necessary for effective viral suppression. Acyclovir is phosphorylated by viral thymidine kinase, leading to incorporation into viral DNA and causing premature chain termination, thereby limiting viral replication. Early administration of IV acyclovir is crucial in reducing morbidity by targeting viral replication.

Key learning point: In adults with varicella pneumonia, especially smokers, intravenous acyclovir is the treatment of choice to reduce severity and duration of the illness.

D) INCORRECT:

The patient's rash and diffuse pulmonary infiltrates suggest a viral exanthem, not bacterial pneumonia, which typically presents with lobar consolidation. The absence of signs of bacterial superinfection, such as robust leukocytosis or hemodynamic instability, argues against broad-spectrum antibiotics. The clinical picture aligns with a viral cause requiring targeted antiviral treatment.

questions.text: You are seeing a 4-year-old boy who is brought to your clinic because of a generalized rash for 3 days. During this time, he has experienced severe itching and difficulty sleeping. He has also had fever, headache, and muscle pain. His temperature is 38.2°C, pulse is 97/min, and blood pressure is 96/60 mm Hg. Skin examination reveals multiple macules, papules, and crusted lesions on the face, trunk, and extremities, as well as a few fluid-filled vesicles on the abdomen and back. There is no cervical lymphadenopathy. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Patients with erythema infectiosum also present with fever and a pruritic rash. However, erythema infectiosum rash is usually only mildly pruritic and initially pronounced on the cheeks (i.e., slapped‑cheek rash) before spreading to the extremities and trunk where it adopts a lace-like and reticular appearance. This patient's highly pruritic rash with fluid-filled vesicles and crusted lesions is inconsistent with erythema infectiosum.

B) INCORRECT:

The rash seen in scarlet fever is typically fine, erythematous, and maculopapular (often described as sandpaper-like), unlike in this patient who presents with macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions. Also, apart from fever, he does not have any symptoms that are characteristically seen in scarlet fever (e.g., throat pain, cervical lymphadenopathy).

C) INCORRECT:

This patient had coryza and fever, both of which are often seen in patients with measles. However, measles typically manifests with a nonpruritic, erythematous, maculopapular, blanching, partially confluent exanthem, which is markedly different from this patient's lesions (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions). Also, this boy does not have any of the symptoms that are typically concomitantly present in measles, such as cough, conjunctivitis, or generalized lymphadenopathy.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's constitutional symptoms (fever, headache, and myalgia) along with a highly pruritic, generalized rash with multiple lesions in different stages (macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) are characteristic of chickenpox. Chickenpox is usually a clinical diagnosis made on the basis of the characteristic rash, although further tests may be necessary in atypical or complicated cases (e.g., older or immunosuppressed patients, pregnant women). A PCR from skin lesions to evaluate for VZV DNA is the preferred test for confirmation.

Key learning point: Chickenpox (varicella) presents with a highly pruritic, generalized rash featuring lesions in various stages—macules, papules, vesicles, and crusts—often accompanied by fever and constitutional symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Roseola infantum primarily affects children between 2 months and 2 years of age and typically manifests with a very high fever that ends abruptly before the sudden appearance of a rash. In contrast, this patient's fever and exanthema are present at the same time. Also, his rash is both maculopapular and papulovesicular, different from the rose-pink maculopapular, patchy, blanching exanthem typically seen in roseola infantum. In addition, roseola infantum almost always presents with cervical and/or occipital lymphadenopathy.
questions.hint: The causative pathogen in this patient's case can remain dormant in dorsal root ganglia and get reactivated after several years, leading to a dermatomal rash with painful blistering.

questions.text: You are seeing an 18-month-old boy brought to your clinic by his mother due to a 2-day history of fever and a pruritic rash. The rash began on his trunk and has since spread to his face and extremities. He has not received any childhood vaccinations because his parents are concerned about vaccine safety. His temperature is 38.0°C. A photograph of the rash is provided. Which one of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Herpes zoster (shingles) is caused by reactivation of the varicella-zoster virus which remains dormant in the dorsal root ganglia. It most commonly occurs in adults over the age of 50 years and classically presents as a painful vesicular rash in a dermatomal distribution. Fever, headaches, and paresthesias may also occur. This patient's rash, which is present in all stages (i.e., macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions) on his trunk, face, and extremities, is not consistent with herpes zoster.

B) INCORRECT:

Rubella (German measles) should be considered in an unvaccinated child with fever and a generalized pruritic rash. However, the rubella rash is typically maculopapular and begins on the face and moves downward (as opposed to this patient's rash) sparing the palms and soles. In addition, rubella is characterized by a prodromal phase in which patients usually present with post-auricular and/or suboccipital lymphadenopathy, neither of which are seen in this child.

C) INCORRECT:

Measles (rubeola) should be considered in an unvaccinated child with fever and a generalized rash. However, the measles rash is typically confluent, nonpruritic, and characteristically begins on the face and moves downward, as opposed to this boy's rash. In addition, the rash is usually preceded by a constellation of symptoms including cough, coryza, conjunctivitis, and enanthem with Koplik spots, none of which are seen in this patient.

D) CORRECT:

Varicella (chickenpox) is caused by the varicella-zoster virus (HHV-3) and is characterized by fever and a generalized pruritic rash in various stages of healing that typically begins on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities. Chickenpox is no longer as common in the United States following the introduction of the varicella vaccine in 1995. Children between 12–15 months of age should receive their first dose of the vaccine and a second dose between ages 4–6.

Key learning point: Varicella (chickenpox) presents as a pruritic, generalized rash in various stages of healing that starts on the trunk and spreads to the face and extremities, often accompanied by fever.

E) INCORRECT:

Roseola infantum (exanthem subitum or sixth disease), which is primarily caused by HHV-6 and, less frequently, by HHV-7, can manifest with a generalized rash and fever. However, children typically present with a 3–7 day history of persistent high-grade fever (may present as febrile seizures) that rapidly subsides, followed by the development of a rose-pink, nonpruritic, blanching maculopapular rash that begins on the trunk. In contrast, this patient's fever and rash appeared simultaneously. Additional features of roseola infantum may include conjunctivitis, orbital edema, inflammation of the tympanic membranes, lymphadenopathy, upper respiratory tract symptoms, and Nagayama spots, none of which are seen in this patient.
questions.hint: A generalized pruritic rash with simultaneous occurrence of macules, papules, vesicles, and crusted lesions indicates infection with human herpesvirus 3.

questions.text: A 4-year-old unvaccinated child presents with a 4-day history of vesicular rash and fever. The rash (shown in photograph) began on the face and trunk and has spread to the extremities. The parents report the child has been scratching intensely, and several lesions now appear purulent with surrounding erythema and warmth. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Direct fluorescent antibody testing on vesicular fluid

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Antiviral therapy is indicated for patients at high risk or with severe infection who present within 72 hours of symptom onset, when the virus is still replicating. This patient is on day 4 of symptoms, and the primary concern is bacterial superinfection rather than viral treatment.

B) INCORRECT:

Topical antibiotics are avoided in chickenpox due to risk of systemic absorption when applied to large areas of broken skin. Oral antibiotics are preferred for bacterial superinfection.

C) INCORRECT:

Chickenpox is usually diagnosed clinically. Confirmatory studies are usually recommended only in the case of diagnostic uncertainty, for infection in vaccinated patients (to distinguish between wild-type strains and vaccine-type strains), and in patients with immunocompromised contacts.

D) INCORRECT:

Supportive care alone is appropriate for uncomplicated chickenpox, but this patient's clinical signs suggest bacterial superinfection. Antibiotic treatment is indicated to prevent progression to more serious complications.

E) CORRECT:

Correct -- The presence of purulent lesions with surrounding erythema and warmth suggests bacterial superinfection, a common complication of chickenpox. Oral antibiotic therapy targeting skin flora pathogens is the appropriate treatment for this secondary bacterial infection.

questions.text: A 34-year-old pregnant woman at 28 weeks' gestation presents to the ED with a 2-day history of fever, myalgia, and a pruritic rash (shown in photograph) that began on her torso but is now widespread. Vital signs are BP, 128/82; P, 96; T, 38.2°C (100.8°F); oxygen saturation, 97% on room air. She reports mild shortness of breath with exertion but denies cough or chest pain. She has no known history of chickenpox or varicella vaccination. What is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Initiate prophylactic oral antibiotic therapy against superinfection
Obtain chest x-ray to determine need for systemic treatment
Discharge with supportive care and obstetric follow-up

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Varicella-zoster immune globulin is used for postexposure prophylaxis in susceptible high-risk individuals, not for treatment of established infection. This patient already has active chickenpox with characteristic lesions.

B) CORRECT:

Correct -- Pregnant individuals with chickenpox require immediate antiviral therapy due to increased risk of varicella pneumonia and other complications.

C) INCORRECT:

Prophylactic antibiotics are not recommended for varicella infections. While bacterial superinfection of chickenpox lesions is managed with antibiotics if it occurs, prophylactic antibiotic therapy is not indicated. The immediate priority for this high-risk pregnant patient is antiviral therapy to prevent serious maternal complications such as varicella pneumonia.

D) INCORRECT:

While chest x-ray may be considered to evaluate for pneumonia, treatment should not be delayed. Pregnant individuals with chickenpox are considered high-risk and require immediate antiviral therapy regardless of chest imaging results.

E) INCORRECT:

Supportive care alone is inappropriate for pregnant individuals with chickenpox due to their significantly increased risk of complications, particularly varicella pneumonia, which occurs in up to 20% of pregnant women with varicella.
